2 parameter model: The 2-parameter Critical Power model uses just CP and Wâ€². CP is your steady-state limit, and Wâ€² is your anaerobic work above CP. It fits a straight-line relationship between power and 1/time.

difference between 2 and 3 parameter: The 2-parameter model is simple and assumes a straight line between power and 1/time. The 3-parameter model adds a curvature term to improve accuracy for short efforts. Both estimate CP and Wâ€², but the 3-parameter version handles high-intensity data better.

equation critical power: The main Critical Power equation is P = (Wâ€² / t) + CP, where P is power, t is time to exhaustion, Wâ€² is your finite work capacity above CP, and CP is your sustainable power limit.
